verb.description: Deprive (a man) of his male role or identity.
examples: he feels emasculated, because he cannot control his sons' behavior

verb.description: Make (a person, idea, or piece of legislation) weaker or less effective.
examples: our winner-take-all elections emasculate fringe parties

origin: Early 17th century: from Latin emasculat- castrated, from the verb emasculare, from e- (variant of ex-, expressing a change of state) + masculus male.
